docs.snippet: TO some people, love is blind, and on Valentine's Day many romantics reach blindly for chocolates or flowers for gifts for their lovers. But Dr. Robert J. Sternberg, an expert on love, says people can do better.     The key to a successful romance...
docs.lead_paragraph: TO some people, love is blind, and on Valentine's Day many romantics reach blindly for chocolates or flowers for gifts for their lovers. But Dr. Robert J. Sternberg, an expert on love, says people can do better. The key to a successful romance, and to a good Valentine's Day gift, said Dr. Sternberg, a psychologist at Yale University who is studying the nature of love, is making the other person feel you can be counted on ''to value me as a person, not as some image, as a professor or lawyer or teacher, but as myself.'' ''The selection has to be really tailored,'' Dr. Sternberg said in an interview in his cluttered office. ''It may be the box of candy,'' he said, but it might also be a night out, away from the children.

headline.main: EXPERT ADVICE ON VALENTINE'S DAY GIVING

docs.snippet: Rod Steiger won an Oscar for the 1967 ''In the Heat of the Night,'' also voted the best picture. It will be shown Wednesday at 8 P.M. on Channel 11. In accepting his earlier award by the New York Film Critics, the actor said, ''I couldn't have don...
docs.lead_paragraph: Rod Steiger won an Oscar for the 1967 ''In the Heat of the Night,'' also voted the best picture. It will be shown Wednesday at 8 P.M. on Channel 11. In accepting his earlier award by the New York Film Critics, the actor said, ''I couldn't have done this part without the understanding and encouragement of my co-star Sidney.'' Nearby, Mr. Poitier looked on, smiling.

docs.snippet: GEORGE YARDLEY, 56 years old, jumped a few inches off the ground, far below the heights he used to attain with the old Fort Wayne Pistons. He tossed in a feathery layup and the announcer, Dave Zinkoff, grated: ''That was George Yardley - tape and ...
docs.lead_paragraph: GEORGE YARDLEY, 56 years old, jumped a few inches off the ground, far below the heights he used to attain with the old Fort Wayne Pistons. He tossed in a feathery layup and the announcer, Dave Zinkoff, grated: ''That was George Yardley - tape and all.'' The fans watching the so-called ''legends'' in the old-timers' game saw the yards of tape wrapped around George Yardley's knees, but only he and his surgeon fully appreciate what lies beneath the tape. With one reconstructed knee and one basically artificial knee, Yardley got the most out of his five minutes - his first basket and his first two rebounds since he retired in 1962 and his knees fell apart. Yardley's enthusiasm at being back in the scoring column again was just another highlight of what is becoming one of the more joyous events in sports - the midseason jamboree that includes a slam-dunk contest, an old-timers' game and today's All-Star Game, not to mention the parties and the homecoming feeling that no other sport quite matches in its all-star efforts. Perhaps it is the independent, verbal pride of basketball, and perhaps it is the new half- haymish , half-show-biz era of David Stern, commissioner only one year.

docs.snippet: Two of Indiana's finest sons - twins, in this case - will be playing basketball in the same backcourt again Saturday when Dick and Tom Van Arsdale appear in the Legends Classic.   The Van Arsdales, who weaved a simultaneous basketball path through...
docs.lead_paragraph: Two of Indiana's finest sons - twins, in this case - will be playing basketball in the same backcourt again Saturday when Dick and Tom Van Arsdale appear in the Legends Classic. The Van Arsdales, who weaved a simultaneous basketball path through high school, college and the pros, will be members of the West squad in the second old-timers contest. The exhibition will be held at Market Square Arena and will be followed by a slam dunk competition. On Sunday, 24 of the National Basketball Association's finest meet in the 35th annual All-Star Game at the Hoosier Dome.

headline.main: Old and New Stars to Perform;    Weekend Of Basketball

docs.snippet: GARY COOPER is, indirectly at least, part of the inspiration for ''Witness.'' Edward S. Feldman, the film's producer, says he thought of Mr. Cooper's performance in ''Friendly Persuasion'' when it came to casting the leading role of John Book, the...
docs.lead_paragraph: GARY COOPER is, indirectly at least, part of the inspiration for ''Witness.'' Edward S. Feldman, the film's producer, says he thought of Mr. Cooper's performance in ''Friendly Persuasion'' when it came to casting the leading role of John Book, the Philadelphia policeman who goes into hiding with an Amish family. ''I thought of Gary Cooper wearing that Quaker outfit,'' Mr. Feldman recalled, ''and I asked myself, 'Who today is a reactive kind of actor who would also look funny in an outfit like that?' '' Harrison Ford came to mind, and the movie was on its way. When Mr. Feldman first came across a draft of the screenplay, by Earl W. Wallace and William Kelley, it was much longer, with sections taking almost a documentarylike approach to the Amish and their customs. ''There was nothing wrong with the writing, but it really needed editing,'' Mr. Feldman recalled. It needed enough to make 20th Century- Fox pass up the screenplay twice; later on, when Mr. Feldman optioned it himself and took the idea to other studios, some had reservations about whether Mr. Ford could carry the whole film. There were a number of turndowns before Paramount finally agreed to make ''Witness,'' which opens today (review on page 16).

docs.snippet: With 11 nominations apiece, ''Amadeus'' and ''A Passage to India'' swept the 57th Academy Award nominations announced today.   ''Amadeus,'' the story of Antonio Salieri's envious hatred for Mozart, and ''A Passage to India,'' based on E. M. Forste...
docs.lead_paragraph: With 11 nominations apiece, ''Amadeus'' and ''A Passage to India'' swept the 57th Academy Award nominations announced today. ''Amadeus,'' the story of Antonio Salieri's envious hatred for Mozart, and ''A Passage to India,'' based on E. M. Forster's novel about the relations between British colonials and Indian natives, will compete head to head in eight categories, including best picture, director, cinematography, costume design and screenplay adaptation. ''Amadeus'' and ''A Passage to India'' were joined in the best-picture category by ''The Killing Fields,'' the story of the search by a reporter for The New York Times for the Cambodian assistant he left behind when Pol Pot's forces swept Cambodia in 1975; ''Places in the Heart,'' a story about a woman's struggle to save her farm and her children in Texas during the Depression, and ''A Soldier's Story,'' about a murder at an Army camp in the South in World War II. ''Places in the Heart'' and ''The Killing Fields'' also tied for runners- up for the most nominations, with seven apiece, including screenplay and director. None of the nominations came as a surprise.

docs.snippet: QUESTION: Has a goaltender ever scored a goal in a National Hockey League game? Did he do it by shooting the puck into an empty net?    Only Billy Smith of the Islanders has ever accomplished this in the league's 68 years and he never took a shot ...
docs.lead_paragraph: QUESTION: Has a goaltender ever scored a goal in a National Hockey League game? Did he do it by shooting the puck into an empty net? Only Billy Smith of the Islanders has ever accomplished this in the league's 68 years and he never took a shot on goal during the play. The incident occurred Nov. 28, 1979 in a game between the Islanders and the Colorado Rockies (now the Devils) in Denver. After the Rockies scored for a 4-3 lead with 45 seconds to go in the second period, Smith replaced Glenn (Chico) Resch in goal. Early in the final period, the referee signaled for a delayed hooking penalty on Mike Kaszycki of the Islanders. That prompted Bill McKenzie, the Colorado goaltender, to leave the ice for a sixth skater, since the whistle would not be blown until the Islanders regained control of the puck.

docs.snippet: Attending the Broadway revival of ''The King and I'' recently, I was reminded of the time when Rodgers and Hammerstein were viewed as pop deities in somewhat the same way that the Beatles and Bob Dylan came to be idolized by the rock countercultur...
docs.lead_paragraph: Attending the Broadway revival of ''The King and I'' recently, I was reminded of the time when Rodgers and Hammerstein were viewed as pop deities in somewhat the same way that the Beatles and Bob Dylan came to be idolized by the rock counterculture a decade and a half later. When ''The King and I'' opened in 1951, World War II was only six years gone. Still flushed with victory, America was settling into the nesting, fortress mentality of the postwar baby boom. Official optimism was the cultural order of the day. ''The King and I'' was Rodgers and Hammerstein's fifth musical collaboration, and at the time it opened, their fourth, ''South Pacific,'' was still running on Broadway. ''South Pacific'' went on to play 1,925 performances, and with the success of ''The King and I,'' which ran for 1,246 performances, Rodgers and Hammerstein assumed the stature of unbeatable winners wearing a moral halo - they personified American self-confidence. The team's refinement of the integrated book musical, in which the interweaving of story, songs and choreography all worked toward a single purpose, fortuitously coincided with the coalescing of a vast, spirtually homogeneous American suburbia.

headline.main: REVIVING A MUSICAL AND AN AGE OF OPTIMISM

docs.snippet: PURCHASE ''THERE must be theater here!'' declared Joan Vinton, the director of the Performing Arts Center at the State University of New York at Purchase for the last two years.     The arts events held here make up a programming potpourri, includ...
docs.lead_paragraph: PURCHASE ''THERE must be theater here!'' declared Joan Vinton, the director of the Performing Arts Center at the State University of New York at Purchase for the last two years. The arts events held here make up a programming potpourri, including chamber music recitals and dance company programs. In what Miss Vinton conceded has been a ''Chinese menu-type'' of series, the theater buff might feel short-changed. Once in a while, a touring company is seen on a one-night stopover.

headline.main: ACTING COMPANY TO APPEAR AT PURCHASE

docs.snippet: Elvia Cosme Hernandez describes herself in a soft voice as a typical mother of two young children, except that, she says, her husband, sister, uncle and cousin were either killed by Salvadoran Government security forces or made to ''disappear.''  ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Elvia Cosme Hernandez describes herself in a soft voice as a typical mother of two young children, except that, she says, her husband, sister, uncle and cousin were either killed by Salvadoran Government security forces or made to ''disappear.'' Their uninvestigated deaths four years ago, Mrs. Hernandez says, led her to join the Committee of Mothers and Relatives of Political Prisoners, Disappeared and Murdered, a vocal group of Salvadoran women who say their loved ones were killed for political reasons. ''I joined because it was necessary to denounce this violation,'' Mrs. Hernandez, 31 years old, said in a recent interview. ''If we don't denounce it, it will go on.''

headline.main: WOMEN'S GRIEF GIVES RISE TO ACTIVISM IN EL SALVADOR
